awd_titl_txt: Neural Investigations of Face Perception and Attention Using Population Receptive Field Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
Every day, our many social interactions with others depend on our ability to recognize people from their faces. However, about 2% of the general population have deficits in face perception. What makes some people good at recognizing faces and others bad at it? Scientists have identified brain regions involved in perceiving faces. Additionally, behavioral research has shown that face perception is "holistic". That is, perception of the whole face, all at once, is better than that of individual facial features. However, it is unknown what neural computations underlie this holistic perception of faces. Because holistic face processing requires spatial integration across face parts, the goal of the research is to examine whether such processing relies on spatial integration by neurons in face-selective brain. Additionally, the research will determine if individual differences in neuronal spatial integration predict individual differences in face recognition ability. This project is expected to impact society in several ways. Understanding the neural mechanisms of face recognition could improve measurement, enhance diagnosis, and ultimately improve the wellbeing of individuals with deficits in face recognition. The project will also develop research infrastructure by making publicly available the new methods and computational tools for measurement and modeling of brain responses. The project intends to advance the participation and education of women in STEM fields.

The research program addresses important gaps in knowledge by leveraging cutting-edge neuroimaging and computational approaches, including population receptive field (pRF) modeling and hierarchical convolution neural networks, together with behavioral measurements of face perception. In particular, the pRF approach offers a unique opportunity to operationalize and measure spatial processing and attentional effects on face perception in a computational framework. Thus, the research (i) will advance understanding of the neural mechanisms of face perception by quantifying spatial aspects of face processing and attention, (ii) will uncover how spatial integration of different face stimuli, under differing attentional demands explains individual differences in face perception abilities, and (iii) will generate an up-to-date and neurally accurate computational model of human face perception.

por.por_cntn:
Humans are incredibly skilled at identifying faces: although each face contains the same features in roughly the same locations, we are finely attuned to the minute differences between individuals. We recognize thousands of unique people over the course of our lifetime, and do so with considerably greater ease than for items of other visual categories, like individual cars or plants. 

For the last 50 years, researchers have noted that we are much worse at recognizing faces presented upside-down, and that this impairment is particularly strong for faces than other objects. This has been conceptualized as a breakdown of holistic face processing - the idea that rather than recognizing faces based on individual features such as eyes, noses, or mouths, we recognize faces as a whole. Indeed, scientists have hypothesized that people are worse at recognizing upside-down faces because unlike for upright faces, recognition of unside-down faces is based on individual features rather than the whole face. While the idea of holistic processing is appealing, until now, we have had little insight as to how this is actually achieved by the human brain. 

A large body of research has shown that neurons in the visual system process visual information in localized regions of the visual field, which scientists call receptive fields. Each neuron's receptive field processes a different part of the visual field. The receptive field aperture of neurons in low-level regions is small (e.g., smaller than your fingernail, an arm-length away), so each neuron processes only a small portion of the visual field. In contrast, neurons in high-level regions, such as face-selective regions that are involved in face recognition, have large receptive field apertures. Because neurons with similar receptive fields are clustered together in the brain, we can use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to measure the population receptive field (pRFs) in local cortical neighborhoods (voxels-volume pixels, measured with fMRI) spanning a few mm on a side. So, we asked: how do pRFs in face-selective regions contribute to and constrain face recognition? 

We hypothesized that pRFs in face-selective regions will be large covering the entire face for upright faces, but smaller in aperture for upside-down faces. To test this hypothesis, we performed an fMRI experiment and computational modeling to estimate pRFs in each voxel of the human brain, then we compared pRFs for upright vs. upside-down faces,

Strikingly, we found that pRFs in face-selective regions - located within a fold of the brain called the fusiform gyrus - were smaller in span and shifted downward when participants saw upside-down faces. That is, when we normally view faces, neurons in our face-selective regions process visual inputs over a large portion of the visual field, centered where we focus our gaze; but when faces are upside-down, the same neurons process a much smaller portion of the visual field that is also shifted downward below our gaze. In other words, the reason we struggle to recognize faces is that typically pRF in face-selective regions adaptively cover and thus process all of the features of a face, but for upside-down faces the pRFs cover only a limited portion of an upside-down face, thus disrupting its processing (see image). 

Given these fMRI findings, we reasoned we may be able to improve recognition of upside-down faces by positioning them slightly lower and to the left of participants' center of gaze, to the location where pRFs for upside-down faces were shifted to. We tested this in a behavioral experiment outside of the fMRI scanner, in which we measured the participants' ability to recognize upright and upside-down faces at the optimal location suggested by our pRF measurements, slightly lower-left of center. Indeed, we found that participants were less impaired in recognizing upside-down faces at this neurally-predicted location. 

Human face recognition is a remarkable feat: we distinguish thousands of individuals based on small differences in facial features, and do so effortlessly and efficiently. The current study opens the door to understanding this incredibly complex behavior through computations done by populations receptive fields of neurons in the human brain. Our findings suggest that even basic neural properties, like the aperture in which each neuron processes visual information, has a profound impact in how we perceive the world. These data have important impact not only for understanding deficits in face recognition (e.g., developmental prosopagnosia or in Autism Spectrum) but also provide an important stepping-stone for using population receptive field modeling to gain important insights about the contributions of neural computations to behavior across domains.
